results.title: The Mallet = Malj (D)
results.brief_description: In a futuristic antiseptic food factory, workers select healthy chicks while the rejects are carried along a conveyor belt until they are crushed by a mallet and dropped into a garbage bin. A single black chick appears among the yellow and is shoved toward the garbage bin. Before the mallet strikes the gasping chick rebels. A terrifying vision of Social Darwinism, rendered as a haunting and powerful allegory. Without narration. Winner of the 1979 Melbourne Film Festival short film competition. NB: CONTAINS DISTURBING IMAGES
results.description: In a futuristic antiseptic food factory, workers select healthy chicks while the rejects are carried along a conveyor belt until they are crushed by a mallet and dropped into a garbage bin. results.title: The Mallee tree
results.creator_credit: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: With its roots deeply set in the earth the humble Mallee finds its strength to face the uncertain challenges of nature. Its tenacity to survive and live on through long droughts and harsh weather conditions is symbolic of the Birchip community who also face similar challenges in their own lives. Written and performed by Glenys Rickard.

results.title: The Mallee Fowl
results.creator_credit: David Moore and Peter Du Cane
results.brief_description: Mallee Fowl are the most remarkable of the world’s mound-building birds. The male bird builds a huge conical mound like a compost heap, which acts as an incubator for hatching the eggs. This fascinating documentary looks at the life-style of this unusual bird.
results.description: Mallee Fowl are the most remarkable of the world’s mound-building birds. The male bird builds a huge conical mound like a compost heap, which acts as an incubator for hatching the eggs. This fascinating documentary looks at the life-style of this unusual bird.
description_for_label: Mallee Fowl are the most remarkable of the world’s mound-building birds. The male bird builds a huge conical mound like a compost heap, which acts as an incubator for hatching the eggs. This fascinating documentary looks at the life-style of this unusual bird.
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: The Mallee fowl
results.brief_description: An account of the nesting habits of the Mallee Fowl. These birds are members of the family Megapodirdae - the mound builders. They do not brood their eggs but lay them on a bed of organic matter in a mound of earth, leaving them to be incubated by heat from fermenting vegetable matter and the natural heat of the sun. The male bird carefully adjusts the mound so that the varying amounts of heat from the two sources maintain the temperature at 92 degrees fahrenheit.

results.title: The Mallaganee boy
results.creator_credit: Dean Lawry, David Meagher, Jason White, Astrid Scott and ACMI Content Development
results.brief_description: David Ferrier is a young farmer operating the family farm 25 km outside Birchip. In this short interview he talks about his relationship with the farm and the land and his unusual hobby of whip cracking.

results.title: The Malay Peninsula: people and products
results.brief_description: An account of life in modern Malaya showing the following: geography of the country; Singapore as a mixture of the civilisations of the East and West; the religions of Malaya; village life; the natural resources, including tin, coconuts, rubber, rice and tea; European influences in Malaya.

results.title: The Making of woollen and worsted yarn
results.brief_description: Silent film illustrating methods of processing raw wool to produce a yarn ready for weaving. Each process is illustrated, first using the simplest of hand equipment and then by modern machine methods. The final sequences compare old and new methods of shearing, carding, combing and spinning.

results.title: The Making of woollen and worsted cloth
results.brief_description: Illustrates how yarn is woven into cloth. The principles of weaving are illustrated on a simple hand loom and then the working of a large power-loom is explained. Various processes needed for finished cloth - fulling, cropping, napping and folding - are illustrated; reconstruction of early hand methods being followed by shots of modern factory machines.

results.title: The Making of the Stooges
results.creator_credit: Operator 13 Productions and Mark S Gilman Jr
results.brief_description: Narrated by Steve Allen, this documentary traces the Three Stooges’ fifty year career from their earliest days as the “Three Lost Souls”. Comprising Larry Fine, Curly Howard, Moe Howard, the Three Stooges developed a wildly unique comic style and were regarded as the kings of slapstick comedy. Featuring rare performance footage and interviews with family, friends and co-workers.

results.title: The Making of the river [B&W]
results.brief_description: Shows how a river forms from many sources: the clouds, melting snow in the mountains and underground springs. It flows throufh canyons and forests, making waterfalls and sometimes quiet pools. Also shows plant and animal life it passes on the journey to the sea, gathering water from joining streams.
